intro: Brassica humilis, commonly known as the wild mustard, is a small, annual herb native to Europe and parts of Asia. It typically grows to a height of about 20–60 cm, featuring alternate, pinnately lobed leaves and small, yellow flowers arranged in racemes. The plant produces small, round pods that contain several seeds, which are often dispersed by wind. Brassica humilis is a member of the Brassicaceae family, characterized by its four-petaled flowers and siliqua fruits. It is often found in disturbed soils and is considered a pioneer species in ecological succession.
